entry.title: Repeat decisions
entry.body: I decide to start exercising, but I keep changing the plan every week. One week it's running, the next it's lifting, then it's yoga. I never stick with any of them.

outputs.editor:
SUMMARY:
You keep changing exercise plans and never stick with one.
FIXES:
- "keep changing": specify how often the plan changes.
- "never stick": clarify how long you typically last.
- "plan": name the criteria for a plan.
REWRITE:
I decide to start exercising but keep changing the plan every week and never stick with any of them.
outputs.definer:
KEY TERMS:
- "changing the plan": switching to a new routine within a week.
- "stick with": following the same routine for at least four weeks.
AMBIGUITIES:
- "every week": could mean weekly or whenever a session is missed.
- "plan": could mean type of workout or schedule.
BOUNDARIES:
- Not claiming: one routine is best.
- Not claiming: exercise is the only goal.
outputs.skeptic:
CORE CLAIM:
Changing routines weekly prevents you from building consistency.
CHALLENGES:
- "keep changing": the issue could be unrealistic time slots rather than routine type.
- "never stick": you may be missing measurement of adherence.
- "one week": short trials can be valid if used intentionally.
TEST:
Follow one routine for 7 days and log each session.
outputs.coach:
INTENT:
You want a consistent exercise routine but keep changing direction.
OPTIONS:
- Commit to running three times this week. Done looks like three logged runs.
- Commit to running three times this week. Done looks like three logged runs.
- Commit to running three times this week. Done looks like three logged runs.
RECOMMENDATION:
Choose running for the next 7 days and ignore other options.
FOR THE NEXT 7 DAYS, STOP:
- Researching other exercise plans
- Switching routines mid-week
